abstract.p: Driven by deep-learning approaches, computational protein design is advancing rapidly, and it is now possible to generate many de novo protein structures quickly and robustly. This sets new frontiers for the field, including designing proteins that bind small molecules tightly and specifically, and understanding the non-covalent interactions that underpin such designs to make binding predictable and tunable. Here we address these challenges with a rapid physics-based computational method to generate isosteric and chemically complementary binding pockets for small-molecule targets in de novo designed proteins. We test this experimentally by constructing and characterizing binding proteins for several synthetic and natural chromophores. By evaluating only single-digit numbers of designs, the pipeline delivers stable proteins with pre-organized binding sites confirmed by X-ray crystallography, which bind the targets selectively with micromolar affinities or better. To illustrate the scope and applications of this approach, we incorporate distinct and coupled chromophore-binding sites in a two-domain de novo protein enabling controlled energy transfer between the two sites, and we develop a small de novo binding protein that can be used in live mammalian cells to visualize sub-cellular structures.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: For some time, protein designers have explored the modelling and construction of small molecule-binding sites in natural and de novo protein scaffolds to enable functions like sensing and catalysis (1–3). Such studies have highlighted the difficulty of achieving high-affinity and highly specific interactions. The routes taken have encompassed all approaches in de novo design, including minimal, rational, and computational strategies. Many of these focus on specific ligands rather than small-molecule binding in general and the need to validate selectivity. For example, Hecht et al. (4) show that combinatorial libraries of sequences tailored to fold into 4-helix bundles have a propensity for heme binding, without embedded design specifications for this. The DeGrado and Dutton groups have successfully incorporated heme binding into de novo 4-helix bundles through rational design and by incorporating nature-inspired binding motifs (2, 5, 6). Baker et al. have used Rosetta to computationally design binders for the steroid digoxigenin into a natural scaffold, initially achieving low-to-mid micromolar affinity, and then improving this to picomolar with library-based mutagenesis and selection (7). De Grado et al. have applied a similar approach to design heme-binding proteins, which are then evolved to achieve high catalytic activity (8, 9). Kortemme et al. have expanded the scope of computational binding-site design by fragmenting ligands and using the fragments in PDB searches to identify optimal contacts (10). Polizzi and De Grado combine fragment-based binding-site design with parametric scaffold generation to develop an apixaban binder with sub-micromolar affinity, and low-nanomolar binders for rucaparib (11–13). Also, Höcker and Jürgens have engineered the E. coli tryptophan repressor to bind auxin as a component of a biosensor in plants (14). Despite these and other successes, these largely physics- and knowledge-based methods are computationally slow, can have limited ligand scope, and usually require careful input and filtering from an expert user (15).

Currently, protein design is undergoing a step-change with the application of deep-learning methods (16). While AI promises to accelerate and simplify de novo binder design, its black-box nature may limit practical and mechanistic understanding of the process. Moreover, early applications of deep-learning methods to deliver small molecule-binding proteins, whilst achieving low-micromolar affinities for cholic acid and methotrexate for instance, still require experimental screening of large numbers of designs per target (17). New pipelines based on scaffold generation using RFDiffusionAA (18) do show improvement for targets that are well represented in structural databases such as heme and bilin. Whilst impressive advances, these studies highlight the considerable challenges that remain in the computational design of small molecule-binding proteins, with even the most advanced methods requiring extensive optimization and screening to achieve experimental successes (15, 19).

To address these issues, we introduce RASSCCoL, a computational pipeline for the Rapid Assessment of Size, Shape, and Chemical Complementarity of Ligands in protein design. This is a robust and interpretable physics-based method for incorporating small molecule-binding sites into protein scaffolds. RASSCCoL’s streamlined pipeline uses the volume and functional groups of the ligand to etch complementary pockets into the proteins. Two key aspects of the work are: (i) the use of fast volume calculations to limit the number of side-chain combinations that need to be assessed, and (ii) the leveraging of a robust, highly stable, and large family of de novo designed α-helical scaffolds. Effectively, this approach allows near-exhaustive sampling of sequences that are most likely to generate pre-organized, isosteric binding sites for the target ligand while bypassing the sampling of backbone flexibility. The resulting sequences are repacked onto the input backbone and are evaluated by ligand docking using AutoDock Vina (20), and then by regenerating the protein folds and binding pockets using AlphaFold2 predictions (21). To address the challenge of exponential scaling for larger ligands and concomitant sequence spaces, we employ machine learning to score designs at the sequence level. This restricts the computationally expensive explicit modelling of structures to the most-promising sequences.

To validate this approach, we create binding sites in single-chain coiled coil-based scaffolds generated through rationally seeded computational protein design (22, 23). These scaffolds have advantages of small size, stability, and well-understood sequence-to-structure relationships. Specifically, they have layered hydrophobic cores that facilitate ligand alignment and side-chain replacement in the computational design. Coiled-coil proteins and protein-protein interfaces are ubiquitous in nature (24), and are amongst the most successful de novo designed proteins targeted to date (25, 26). In principle, however, RASSCCoL can be applied to any protein scaffold. Combined, this pipeline simplifies the design process, requires minimal user input, produces robust in silico models that are chemically derived and interpretable, limits the number of constructs for experimental testing, and yields high success rates of confirmed binders. We show that RASSCCoL can be used to introduce orthogonal but coupled binding sites to produce more-complex, functional de novo proteins; and to deliver small de novo chromophore-binding proteins for use as fluorescent reporters in cells.

sec.title: A physics-based computational pipeline for binding-site design
sec.p: Initially to develop and illustrate RASSCCoL, we chose a compact and stable de novo designed 4-helix bundle, sc-apCC-4 (PDB id 8a3k), as the protein scaffold (22); and two synthetic, environment-sensitive dyes—1,6-diphenyl-1,3,5-hexatriene (DPH) and Nile red—as the target ligands (27). Our computational pipeline for generating small molecule-binding sites had three generalizable steps (Figure 1): (i) binding-site selection; (ii) sequence generation and culling; (iii) model building, ligand docking, and evaluation.

First, the positions of binding-site residues were identified based on ligand length. The core packing in sc-apCC-4 is layered with four side chains per layer and a spacing of ≈5 Å between layers. Thus, the number of layers that need to be redesigned to accommodate a ligand can be estimated as ligand length in Å divided by 5 (Figure 1A). Second, a volume calculation based on Bondi radii (28) was used to identify side-chain permutations to generate voids that match the ligand’s volume most closely. The 2-fold symmetric and entirely hydrophobic ligand DPH (length, L ≈ 15 Å; and volume, V ≈ 274 Å3; Figure 1A) spans three 4-residue layers of sc-apCC-4. Within these layers, we retained some of the Ile residues important for fold stability (22). This left ten designable positions in total, which we restricted to combinations of the aliphatic residues, Gly, Ala, Val, Leu and Ile (Table S1). Thus, potentially, ≈10 million sequence combinations (510) could have been searched. However, this reduced to ≈3,200 sequences by applying the ligand-volume and ligand-symmetry constraints (Figure 1B, Table S1). Third, using FASPR (29) each sequence was repacked into the scaffold structure, and DPH was docked into the resulting models using AutoDock Vina (Figure 1B) (20). AutoDock Vina employs a physics-based scoring function to predict ligand-binding poses and affinities, which we used to score the models. Combined, these computational steps took tenths of a second for each sequence (Figure S1), enabling the entire design protocol to finish within 30 minutes on a single CPU core (Table S1). Finally, AlphaFold2 (AF2) was used to predict structures for a small number of the top-scoring sequences, followed by docking to evaluate ligand-pose recovery (Figure 1B, Table S2). These provided assessment metrics to choose only a small number of designs for experimental production and characterization (Figure S3, Table S3). To evaluate how RASSCCoL extended to asymmetric ligands we targeted Nile red (L ≈ 13 Å; V ≈ 324 Å3; Figure S2). In this case, the sequence space was significantly larger at ≈400,000 possible sequences after applying the volume constraint (Tables S1, Figure S4). By parallelizing this approach to utilize multiple CPU threads, the computations for Nile red were completed in less than 2 hours.

In summary, RASSCCoL enables in silico screening of hundreds of thousands of designed sequences within hours even with modest computational resources (Table S1, Figure S1). This allows users to embellish the RASSCCoL pipeline as needed, for instance to include molecular dynamics (MD) simulations to explore wider backbone and side-chain conformational space (Figures S8 – 9).

sec.title: Direct, rapid, and robust generation of small molecule-binding proteins
sec.p: For experimental testing, we chose five target ligands of varying volume, polarity, and heteroatom content (Figure 2A, Figure S2): the aforementioned hydrophobic fluorophores DPH (L ≈ 15 Å; V ≈ 274 Å3) and Nile red (L ≈ 13 Å; V ≈ 324 Å3); more-hydrophilic and biologically relevant lumiflavin (L ≈ 11 Å; V ≈ 257 Å3); and biologically active arcyriaflavin A (L ≈ 12 Å; V ≈ 310 Å3) and SN38 (L ≈ 14 Å; V ≈ 396 Å3). For each ligand, we introduced up to ten mutations into three layers of the sc-apCC-4 scaffold (Figure 2B and Table S1). For lumiflavin, arcyriaflavin A and SN38, the side-chain libraries were diversified to include small polar residues, Ser, Thr, Asn, and Asp (Table S1). In this way, we aimed to accommodate the polar functional groups of these ligands, hypothesizing that these would be captured by the AutoDock scores in the RASSCCoL pipeline (Figures S5 – 8). Indeed, binding-site sequences with polar amino acids were returned for these ligands (Figure 2B, Figure S10). RASSCCoL calculations and full-length sequences of designs made as synthetic genes are summarized in Tables S1 and S3.

To test the robustness of both RASSCCoL and the sc-apCC-4 scaffold, we selected just thirteen sequences for characterization based on the docking scores: two for DPH, with clockwise and anticlockwise arrangements of the helices predicted by AF2 (Figure S11) but with the same binding-site solution; two each for Nile red and arcyriaflavin A; three for lumiflavin; and four for SN38 (Table S3 and Figures S3 – 8). All proteins expressed well, were monomeric, α helical, and thermally stable (Figures S12 – 14). Binding assays using fluorescence intensity (FI) or fluorescence polarization (FP) measurements returned sub-micromolar affinities for DPH and arcyriaflavin A, low-micromolar affinities for Nile red and SN38, and a weaker ≈50 uM affinity for lumiflavin (Figures S15 – 19). Interestingly, and although ligand selectivity was not explicitly included in the RASSCCoL pipeline, we found that many of the designed proteins discriminated between the different small molecules (Table S5, Figure S20). Notably, the sc-apCC-4-DPH-1 and sc-apCC-4-NR-1 proteins, with designed hydrophobic binding pockets, did not bind the more hydrophilic lumiflavin—despite its smaller molecular volume compared to DPH and Nile red—consistent with the lack of chemical complementarity (Table S5, Figure S20).

As controls to test the robustness of the scaffold and any ligand binding through non-specific interactions, we mutated the targeted binding site residues to either all Gly or all Ala to give sc-apCC-4-Gly and sc-apCC-4-Ala, respectively. Despite high AF2 confidence (Table S2), the sc-apCC-4-Gly was completely unfolded (Figure S13, top). However, the sc-apCC-4-Ala mutant was monomeric, α helical, and thermally stable (Figures S12 – 14). It bound target ligands at least one order of magnitude weaker than the best designed binders (Table S5, Figures S15 – 20). Interestingly, arcyriaflavin A was the most promiscuous ligand in our panel, and it was the only ligand to bind the Ala-based control with μM affinity.

We determined high-resolution crystal structures of the ligand-free forms for all five de novo binders. (Figure 3, Table S6 – 7). The DPH binder crystalized as a domain-swapped dimer despite being monomeric in solution (Figures S21 – 22). Nonetheless, each domain aligned well with the AF2 model, with the designed binding site geometry maintained (Figure 3A). The Nile red, lumiflavin, arcyriaflavin A and SN38 binders matched the respective AF2 models closely with overall root-mean square differences between the Cα atoms (Cα-RMSDs) of < 0.5 Å (Figure 3B – E). All five apo-proteins structures revealed solvent accessible, pre-organized binding pockets with side-chain geometries close to those predicted by AF2 (Figure 3A – E) and binding-site heavy atom RMSDs of < 0.5 Å. Thus, the observed cavity shapes and volumes matched the computational designs closely. Despite multiple attempts, we did not obtain any crystals for the ligand:protein complexes. However, redocking the ligands into the crystal structures returned almost identical poses to the computational design models (Figure 3A – D). The only exception was the SN38 binder, where docking positioned the ligand within the binding pocket of the crystal structure, but not in the AF2 model (Figure 3E). Moreover, for lumiflavin, arcyriaflavin A and SN38, inspection of the structures and docking predictions revealed hydrogen bonds between the ligands and introduced polar side chains (Figure 3C – E).

sec.title: RASSCCoL can be scaled for larger ligands and de novo scaffolds
sec.p: Traditional protein design methods that explore combinations of side chains do not scale well with increasing number of designable positions and large amino-acid palettes (30–32). For our de novo scaffolds, significant reduction of the sequence space is possible by exploiting the symmetry, layered structures, and well-understood sequence-to-structure relationships of α-helical bundles. However, in more general cases using RASSCCoL, even with its optimized and relatively fast model-building and docking steps, the process would become computationally expensive once sequence space exceeded a few million. To mitigate this, we implemented an active sequence sampling strategy using Gradient Boosted Trees (GBT) (33). This prioritizes the most-informative data points rather than exhaustively docking all possible sequences, significantly reducing computational cost and time (Figures S23 – 24).

To test this approach, we used a recently designed antiparallel 6-α-helix barrel, sc-apCC-6 (PDB id 8qad) (23). Unlike sc-apCC-4, this has a central hydrophobic cavity that binds DPH with low-micromolar affinity but has a weaker affinity for Nile red (Figure S25). We aimed to reverse this selectively and design a variant that bound Nile red but not DPH by exploiting only shape complementarity using RASSCCoL. The smaller 4-helix bundle required redesigning both a and d core positions of the a→g coiled-coil sequence repeats to generate binding sites (Figure S26A – C). However, due to the increased radius and changes in core packing of the 6-helix barrel (23), we reasoned that redesigning only a positions should accommodate the ligands (Figure S26D – F). In addition, the larger scaffold allowed the amino-acid pallet to be expanded to include Phe, which the 4-helix bundle cannot accommodate. Even by restricting designs to just the a sites of three layers and a subset of hydrophobic residues (Gly, Ala, Val, Leu, Ile, and Phe), this still generated ≈1.3 million sequences after the cavity volume filter. Using active sampling with GBT, only 100,000 sequences were evaluated using Auto Dock Vina, thus reducing the computation by over tenfold.

In more detail, GBT predictors were initially trained on a small, randomly selected subset of RASSCCoL designs of Nile red binders in the sc-apCC-6 background, and these were used to predict AutoDock Vina scores for the remaining sequences. The training set was then iteratively expanded by explicitly docking sequences with the highest prediction uncertainty (i.e., knowledge gaps), the lowest predicted docking scores (i.e., most-promising binders), and randomly chosen sequences to ensure smooth sampling of the sequence space. This process of docking and retraining continued until no further improvement in predictor’s mean-squared error was observed on a randomly selected validation set. At this stage, any remaining unsampled sequences with predicted docking scores below a user-defined cutoff were explicitly docked and passed to the final stages of the RASSCCoL pipeline — filtering and refolding.

Again, we only tested two of the resulting designs experimentally: one intended to bind both ligands equally well (sc-apCC-6-DPH-NR, labelled P for promiscuous), and another specific for Nile red (sc-apCC-6-NR, labelled S for specific) (Figure 4A). Both proteins expressed well, were monomeric, α helical, and thermally stable (Figure S12 – 14). As predicted, we observed low-μM affinities for DPH and Nile red in the promiscuous binder (Figure 4B, panel P). By contrast, the selective binder exhibited 170-fold tighter binding for Nile red compared to DPH, with a sub-μM dissociation constant for the former (Figure 4B, panel S). Inspection of the docked AF2 models suggests that selectivity against DPH—which is ≈2 Å longer than Nile red—arises from subtle shortening of the binding pocket, causing steric clashes between DPH and residues at the extremes of the binding pocket (Figure 4C).

Nile red is an environment-sensitive probe (34). This is apparent in changes in its emission spectrum upon binding to the P and S designs (Figure 4D): i.e., the resolved vibronic bands similar to those seen in n-hexane; and the blue-shifted fluorescence peak relative to that observed in dioxane and the more-solvent-exposed binding site of sc-apCC-4-NR-1 (27, 35). This infers binding to tight hydrophobic pockets of the P and S designs. Finally, we solved a structure of P without ligand to 3.2 Å. This matched the AF2 model with Cα-RMSD of 0.3 Å (Figure 4E, PDB id 9R1O). Despite the medium resolution, electron density for the designed residues—particularly the Phe side chains—was well-resolved (Figure 4E). Redocking the ligands into this structure produced poses that closely aligned with the designed models (Figure 4F).

sec.title: RASSCCoL yields modular fluorescent proteins for applications in vitro and in mammalian cell
sec.p: Building beyond single-domain, small molecule-binding proteins will require generating binding sites (or binding modules) that are orthogonal and can be co-assembled in modular manner into more-complex de novo frameworks. To explore this, we used two of the designed 4-helix bundles that bind DPH and Nile red selectively (sc-apCC-4-DPH-1 and sc-apCC4-NR-1, Table S5, Figure S20) to construct a two-domain de novo protein with the domains fused via a rigid, read-through helical linker (Figure 5A). Since DPH and Nile red are a known Förster resonance energy transfer (FRET) pair (27, 36) (Figure S27), we designed this construct to position the two dyes strategically at the Förster distance of ≈50 Å. The resulting protein was expressed in E. coli, and was monomeric, α-helical and thermally stable (Figures S12 – 14). Small-angle X-ray scattering (SAXS) indicated an extended overall conformation consistent with the model (Figure 5A & B). The protein retained its affinities for both ligands (Figure 5C). Moreover, with both ligands present, selective excitation of DPH resulted in both DPH and Nile red fluorescence (Figure 5D & S29 - 30). The latter must arise from FRET and thus indicates a population of the protein with both DPH and Nile red bound. The FRET lifetime of ≈2 ns gave a predicted distance of ≈51 Å, consistent with MD simulations (Figure S31) and experimentally confirming the design of the dual binder (Figure 5E).

Finally, we explored the potential for using the de novo synthetic chromophore-binding proteins to target and visualize subcellular structures in mammalian cells. There are advantages of using de novo fluorescent proteins for such applications. For instance, at ≈130 residues and ≈15 kDa, sc-apCC-4 variants are approximately half the size of commonly used GFP variants (37) and on par with some of the smallest FPs, such as: iLOV (13 kDa) (38); SNAP-tag FP mimics (20 kDa) (39); de novo β-barrels (14 kDa) (40); and transmembrane 4-helix bundles (21 kDa) (41). Moreover, bright fluorophore encapsulation within proteins generally leads to improved and tunable spectral properties compared to conventional FPs. To examine this, we found that Nile red bound to sc-apCC-4-SN38-1, had a high fluorescence quantum yield and thus brightness (ε552 = 52 400 cm-1 M-1; Φ= 0.9), and a long fluorescence lifetime (τ = 4.5 ns) (Table S8 & Figure S32). This is brighter and longer lived than conventional fluorescent proteins in the same spectral region, such as mCherry (ε587 = 72 000 cm-1 M-1; Φ= 0.2; τ = 1.4 ns) (42). Furthermore, emission wavelengths can be tuned toward the near-infrared (NIR) by substituting Nile red for derivatives with similarly high quantum yields, brightness and long fluorescence lifetimes; e.g., Nile blue (ε627 = 34 400 cm-1 M-1; Φ= 0.74; τ = 4.2 ns) (Table S8 & Figures S33 – 35) (43). On this basis, we tested several of our de novo protein modules directly in HeLa cells as fusions to GFP, without and with peptide tags for directing the constructs to different subcellular regions (Table S4, Figure S36). This is illustrated below for sc-apCC-4-SN38-1 (Figure 5F), which binds both Nile red and Nile blue; KD,Nile Red ≈ 0.2 μM and KD,Nile blue ≈ 0.4 μM (Table S5, Figure S20 & 33).

As a control, we fused the parent sc-apCC-4 to the N terminus of mEmerald variant of the green fluorescent protein and transformed the construct into HeLa cells (Table S4, Figure S36). The transiently expressed fusion protein was dispersed throughout the cell. Next, we added short, N-terminal peptide sequences to the fusion to target: the nucleus with a nuclear-localization signal (NLS) (44); the plasma membrane with a Fyn-tag (45); and the actin network with LifeAct (46) (Table S4). In all cases, the mEmerald signal was redistributed and located as expected (Figure S36). These experiments were performed with 0.1 μM Nile red added to the cell media 30 minutes before imaging. However, with these non-Nile-red-binding controls, none of the images showed any coincidence of the mEmerald and Nile red signals. By contrast, when sc-apCC-4 was substituted with sc-apCC-4-NR-1 or sc-apCC-4-SN38-1, the mEmerald and Nile red signals were coincident as evident in the merged images (Figures 5F & S36). These indicate that the dye was taken up by cells and sequestered by the designed Nile red-binding components of the fusion proteins. Interestingly, the images were sharper and clearer with the sc-apCC-4-SN38-1 design. We attribute this to its sub-μM affinity for Nile red, which is 10-fold tighter than for sc-apCC-4-NR-1 (Table S5 and Figure S20). Finally, to demonstrate that sc-apCC-4 alone is sufficient as a de novo fluorescent protein chassis, we repeated the experiments without the mEmerald reporter, and these worked similarly to the fusion constructs showing robust staining of targeted subcellular structures (Figure S37).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Designing proteins that bind small molecules tightly and specifically is a key challenge for protein design and synthetic biology, with potential applications including bioimaging, in vivo sensing, catalysis and therapeutics (15). Here we present RASSCCoL, a fast, efficient, and intuitive computational strategy for introducing small molecule-binding sites into de novo designed proteins. This works by replacing side chains of the de novo scaffold to create cavities that are isosteric with the target ligand. The calculations are vastly accelerated by: i) using a volume filter to enrich for sequences most likely to accommodate the ligand; ii) rapid modelling with FASPR (29) and AutoDock (20); (iii) evaluation of the models using statistical and physical metrics; and iv), where needed for large targets, an active-learning procedure to reduce the number of explicit modelling steps. To put this approach into practice, we leverage well-understood, mutable, and thermostable de novo proteins as the scaffolds; namely, a growing family of single-chain α-helical bundles and barrels (22, 23). This streamlines the design process even further by bypassing backbone optimization and focusing on sequence design and refinement.

Specifically, we have designed low-to-sub-micromolar protein binders for two hydrophobic fluorophores, DPH and Nile red; for lumiflavin, a proxy for flavin-based cofactors; and for two cytotoxic compounds, arcyriaflavin A and SN38. The last three feature polar functional groups that RASSCCoL accommodates with complementary polar side chains. In each case, successful designs are achieved by testing just 1 - 4 expressed genes in E. coli. The approach scales well to larger scaffolds, or with additional design constraints such as ligand selectivity, which we also demonstrate experimentally. To test the modularity of some of the resulting designs, we combine two different binding modules for DPH and Nile red (a known FRET pair) in a two-domain protein that holds the chromophores in a specified orientation and at a set distance to enable energy transfer between the two sites. Finally, we demonstrate the potential of our designs as small (≈15 kDa), stable, mutable, and adaptable fluorescent protein tags for visualizing subcellular structures and processes in mammalian cells.

Together with advances by others (12, 13, 41), our findings reinforce how the use of straightforward, well-understood, and fully characterized de novo scaffolds can accelerate functional protein design. In this way, RASSCCoL offers a robust and interpretable platform for creating next-generation protein-based tools and modules for broader applications in cell and synthetic biology, diagnostics, and therapeutics.

sec.title: Data and materials availability
sec.p: The coordinate and structure factor files for sc-apCC-4-DPH-2, sc-apCC-4-NR-1, sc-apCC-4-LMF-1, sc-apCC-4-A7F-1, sc-apCC-4-SN38-1 and sc-apCC-6-DPH-NR have been deposited in the PDB with accession codes 9R1N, 9R1J, 9R1M, 9R1K, 9R1L, 9R1K and 9R1O, respectively. Data from this study are openly available in Zenodo at DOI: 10.5281/zenodo.15333152. The code to run the RASSCCoL protocol can be found in the Woolfson group GitHub (https://github.com/woolfson-group/RASSCCoL).

caption.title: The RASSCCoL computational protein design pipeline illustrated by DPH binding.
caption.p: (A) A potential site for DPH binding (Lcav) is identified based on the ligand length (Llig). To match the ligand’s shape, the protein scaffold is segmented into corresponding layers (magenta and green). A volume constraint is used to minimize the difference between the binding cavity (Vcav) and the ligand (Vlig) in each layer; effectively, replacing atoms of the side chains with those of the ligand. (B) Design and evaluation strategy showing the numbers of sequences at each step of DPH-binder design. In this case, the sequence library allows only aliphatic amino acids in the binding pocket. Sequences passing the volume constraint are packed onto the scaffold for ligand docking. Structures with the most-negative predicted binding energies in AutoDock Vina are modelled using AlphaFold2 (AF2) and the ligands redocked. Two high-confidence designs with the best redocking scores are selected for experimental testing.

caption.title: RASSCCoL generates low-μM binders to a range of ligands in a starting scaffold devoid of cavities.
caption.p: (A) Ligands tested for binding, top to bottom: DPH (blue-colored panels), Nile red (red), lumiflavin (cyan), arcyriaflavin A (green), and SN38 (yellow). (B) Binding-site residues within the hydrophobic core of the 4-helix bundle, sc-apCC-4 (PDB id 8a3k). (C) Structure predictions of the binders from AF2 with ligands docked using Autodock Vina. (D) Saturation-binding data measured by fluorescence intensity (FI) or fluorescence polarization (FP). Fitted dissociation constants, top to bottom: KD(DPH) = 1.25 ± 0.07 μM; KD(Nile red) = 2.4 ± 0.06 μM; KD(lumiflavin) = 51.64 ± 1.23 μM; KD(arcyriaflavin A) = 0.11 ± 0.02 μM; KD(SN38) = 6.92 ± 1.55 μM. Conditions: 0.5 μM DPH/Nile red or 1 μM lumiflavin/SN38/arcyriaflavin A, 0 – 60 μM protein, PBS, pH 7.4, and with either 10% v/v MeCN (DPH/Nile red/arcyriaflavin A) or 10% v/v DMSO (lumiflavin/SN38) as the solvent for the small molecule. The data shown are the mean of three independent repeats, with error bars representing the standard deviations from the means. For simplicity, only the highest-affinity protein for each ligand is shown, see Figures S15 – 19 for the other designs.

caption.title: Binding-site models generated by RASSCCoL closely match ligand-free crystal structures.
caption.p: Binding-site heavy atom alignments between AlphaFold2 models (gray) and the experimental X-ray crystal structures (colored as in Figure 2): (A) The DPH binder, sc-apCC-4-DPH-2, at 2.4 Å resolution (with a root-mean square difference between the side-chain heavy atoms (sc-RMSD) = 0.45 Å, PDB id 9R1N). Only one domain of the domain-swapped dimer is shown, see Figure S22. (B) The Nile red binder, sc-apCC-4-NR-1, at 1.7 Å resolution (sc-RMSD = 0.33 Å, PDB id 9R1J), (C) The lumiflavin binder, sc-apCC-4-LMF-1, at 2.4 Å resolution (sc-RMSD = 0.30 Å, PDB id 9R1M). (D) The arcyriaflavin A binder, sc-apCC-4-A7F-1, at 2.3 Å resolution (sc-RMSD = 0.35 Å, PDB id 9R1K) (E) The SN38 binder, sc-apCC-4-SN38-1, at 1.85 Å resolution (sc-RMSD = 0.38 Å, PDB id 9R1L). The right-hand column shows docked poses and AutoDock Vina scores for the target ligands within the crystal structures, overlaid with the docked poses within the AF2 models (gray). Binding-site residues are highlighted and shown as sticks, with oxygen atoms in red and nitrogen atoms in blue. Hydrogen bonds are shown as dashed green lines. The X-ray crystal structures were energy-minimized using Rosetta prior to docking. This was done to relax some of the peripheral side chains that were not fully resolved in the experimental maps.

caption.title: RASSCCoL-generated promiscuous and selective binders for DPH and Nile red.
caption.p: (A) AutoDock Vina scores for DPH and Nile red docked into AF2 models for the top 1000 generated designs. The dashed line is the 1:1 diagonal, and the Nile red binders are labelled P (promiscuous) and S (selective). (B) Saturation binding curves and fits for Nile red and DPH to the proteins. Left, promiscuous binder, KD(DPH) = 1.9 ± 0.17 μM, KD(Nile red) = 2.20 ± 0.17 μM. Right, the specific binder, KD(DPH) = 18.77 ± 11.45 μM, KD(Nile red) = 0.11 ± 0.04 μM. (C) AF2 model for the specific binder with DPH docked. Selectivity against DPH is achieved by Leu and Phe residues (red) that shorten the binding site. Severe clashes between DPH and the side chains (overlap > 1 Å) are shown in black. (D) Normalized emission spectrum for Nile red after excitation at 500 nm in aqueous solution with the specific and promiscuous 6-helix binders, compared to the 4-helix Nile red binder and organic solvents. (E) Structural alignment between the AlphaFold2 model (gray) and the experimental X-ray crystal structure of the promiscuous binder P (sc-apCC-6-DPH-NR) at 3.2 Å resolution (Cα RMSD = 0.294 Å, PDB id 9R1O). NCS-averaged electron density for the designed residues is shown at 1σ level in blue. (F) Docked poses of DPH and Nile red in the crystal structure of the promiscuous binder P, overlaid with the design target (docked ligands within the AF2 model; gray). Oxygen atoms shown in red and nitrogen atoms in blue. The crystal structure was energy-minimized using Rosetta prior to docking. Binding conditions: 0.5 μM ligand, 0 – 60 μM protein, PBS, 10% v/v MeCN, pH 7.4. Data are the mean of three independent repeats, error bars represent the standard deviation from the mean.

caption.title: RASSCCoL-derived functional fluorescent proteins.
caption.p: (A – E) A double-binder that transfers energy from DPH (blue) to Nile red (red). (A) AF2 model of the double-binder that combines sc-apCC-4-DPH-1 and sc-apCC-4-NR-1, superposed to the averaged ab initio model from small angle X-ray scattering data. DPH and Nile red are docked with AutoDock Vina. (B) Small angle X-ray scattering data and FoXS (47) fit to the AF2 model (red, χ2 = 1.44). Standard error shown in gray. (C) Saturation binding curves and fits: blue, KD(DPH) = 1.33 ± 0.41 μM; red, KD(Nile red) = 0.53 ± 0.05 μM. (D) Fluorescence lifetime decay measurements for DPH (blue, < 450 nm) and Nile red (red, >600 nm) after selective excitation of DPH at 352 nm. The delayed rise in Nile red emission over the first few nanoseconds originates from Förster resonance energy transfer between DPH and Nile red. In contrast, control measurements that excited only Nile red (Figure S30) showed no delayed emission. Bi-exponential fit of the data returned τFRET = 2.0 ± 0.2 ns, yielding an inter-ligand distance of 51.0 ± 1.3 Å. The expected distance from MD simulations of the model from panel A was 54.0 ± 1.8 Å, see Figure S31. (E) Kinetic model for energy transfer between DPH and Nile red, derived from panel D and direct excitation of DPH and Nile red in isolation (Figures S29 & 30). Binding conditions: 0.5 μM ligand, 0 – 60 μM protein in PBS, 10% v/v MeCN, pH 7.4. Binding data are the mean of three independent repeats, error bars represent the standard deviation from the mean. SAXS conditions: 5 mg/ml protein in PBS, pH 7.4. (F) De novo designed fluorescent protein for subcellular imaging. (Top row) Fluorescence confocal microphotographs of live HeLa cells transiently expressing a fusion of sc-apCC-4-SN38-1 and mEmerald, and stained by adding 0.1 μM Nile red and Hoechst 33342 to the cell media 30 minutes before imaging. (Rows 2 – 4) Similar images for additional fusions with N-terminal tags for locating the proteins to the nucleus, plasma membrane, and actin filaments. Merge (right-hand column): mEmerald (green), NR (red), and Hoechst 33342 (blue). Maximum z-projections are shown for constructs with cytosolic and nuclear localization, single-z slices are shown for actin- and membrane-targeting fusions; scalebars = 20 μm.
